title: 108_s668
content: The "Child Care Quality Incentive Act of 2003" is the short title of this Act. The purpose of the Act is to improve child care quality. The "Child Care Quality Incentive Act of 2003" aims to enhance child care quality by addressing findings such as the importance of early learning and nurturing care, the prevalence of children in child care, and the varying quality of child care centers. Full-day child care costs $4,000 to $12,000 per year, with limited Federal assistance available. Families with incomes under $1,200 spend 25% of their income on child care. Low payment rates for child care providers impact the quality of care and accessibility for families. Low payment rates for child care providers force cuts that impact quality, including staff reductions and fewer educational activities. Low-quality child care leads to delayed skills and increased aggression in children. Higher payment rates improve quality by attracting qualified staff and providing necessary resources. The purpose of this Act is to enhance child care quality. The purpose of this Act is to improve the quality of child care by increasing payment rates. The Act aims to enhance child care quality by raising payment rates. The Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 is amended to include provisions for conducting market rate surveys to ensure payment rates for child care services are comparable in terms of quality and types of services provided. The State must conduct surveys every 2 years to set payment rates ensuring equal access to services. Adjustments for cost of living increases must be made between surveys as specified by the Secretary. The State must conduct surveys every 2 years to set payment rates reflecting variations in child care costs for different ages and types of care. Results of the survey must be made public within 30 days. Incentive grants are provided to improve the quality of child care. Authorization of $500,000,000 in funds for grants to improve child care quality from 2004 to 2008 under the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act. Amendments are made to the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990, including changes to subparagraphs and the establishment of a program. Additionally, grants to improve the quality of child care are authorized with a funding allocation of $500,000,000 from 2004 to 2008. Grants to improve the quality of child care are authorized with a funding allocation of $500,000,000 from 2004 to 2008. The Secretary will use funds to make grants to eligible States and Indian tribes for child care services. Eligible States must have conducted a recent survey of market rates for child care services. To be eligible for a grant under this section, a State must have conducted a market rates survey within 2 years before submitting an application. The application must include details of the survey methodology and results. The State's plan to increase payment rates for child care providers must reflect variations in the cost of care for different ages and types of care, in accordance with market survey results. The State must prioritize increasing payment rates for high-quality care, care for children with disabilities or in child protective services, and care in communities served by struggling educational agencies. The State must ensure timely payments and follow market practices for child absentee days. They should also make survey results widely available to the public to remain eligible for subsequent annual payments under the Secondary Education Act of 1965. The State must conduct regular surveys to maintain increased payment rates under the Secondary Education Act of 1965. To be eligible for third or subsequent annual payments, the State must update the survey every 2 years and provide matching funds of at least 20 percent of the costs for the activities. State contributions for child care assistance grants must be in cash and cannot include Federal Government funds. Eligible States must prioritize increasing payment rates up to the 100th percentile of the market rate survey. Once reaching this rate, States can use the funds for additional purposes with approval from the Secretary. The market rate survey can be used to enhance child care services in the State. Funds should supplement, not replace, other sources of funding. States must report on efforts to increase payment rates and their impact on child care quality. The Secretary will submit biennial reports to Congress on the impact of payment rates on child care quality and access. The term 'payment rate' refers to reimbursement rates for subsidized child care. The Secretary will determine how these provisions apply to Indian tribes and tribal organizations. The Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 is amended to specify payments from appropriated funds and adjust the allotment process. The Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 is amended to adjust the allotment process by inserting "an allotment made under subsection (b)" and adding "corresponding" before "allotment" in paragraph (3).
